Introduction

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive, uncontrollable anxiety and worry about a range of everyday issues (eg, finances, health, relationships).  The anxiety, which is associated with physical, emotional, and cognitive symptoms, results in significant functional impairment.

Epidemiology and risk factors



The estimated lifetime prevalence of GAD is 4%.  Onset is typically during adulthood (usually the patient's 30s), and women appear to be affected at a higher rate than men (2:1 ratio).



Several factors may increase the likelihood of developing GAD, including genetic predisposition, psychological factors (eg, neuroticism, behavioral inhibition, introversion), and environmental factors (eg, parental overprotection, adverse childhood events, stressful/traumatic life events).

Clinical presentation



Anxiety is a general sense of unease about a perceived threat or unknown outcome and includes cognitive (eg, worry, concentration difficulties) and physical (eg, sweating, sleep disturbances) symptoms.  Worry is characterized by repetitive, negative thinking (eg, worst possible outcome) about a specific, future event (eg, failing an upcoming examination).



Intermittent anxiety and worry are normal and can be productive (eg, in finding a solution to a problem or in making a decision).  GAD results when anxiety and worry about routine, everyday issues are excessive (ie, out of proportion to how likely the anticipated event is to occur) and difficult to control.  Topics of anxiety and worry commonly include:



  • Personal health and safety (eg, "What if I get in a car accident on the way to work?")
  • Health and safety of family members
  • Finances (eg, "What if I go bankrupt?")
  • Logistics/travel (eg, "What if I miss my flight and never get back home?")
  • Quality of work/school performance (eg, "What if my presentation does not go well and I flunk out of school?")


The anxiety and worry in GAD must be accompanied by â‰¥3 of the following symptoms:



  • Emotional:  irritability
  • Cognitive:  difficulty concentrating
  • Physical:  restlessness, fatigue, sleep disturbances, muscle tension


Due to high levels of anxiety and worry and an inability to tolerate uncertainty, patients may take longer to complete tasks and/or repeat tasks multiple times, seek excessive reassurance/approval from others, and be overly conforming to rules or requests.



GAD can also be associated with additional physical symptoms (eg, diarrhea, frequent urination, abdominal pain, headaches) as well as panic attacks.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of GAD, the following criteria must be met:



  • Excessive anxiety and worry (apprehensive expectation) about a number of events or activities (eg, work or school performance) occur more days than not for â‰¥6 months.
  • The patient finds it difficult to control the worry.
  • The anxiety and worry are associated with â‰¥3 of the following symptoms (with at least one symptom present most days for â‰¥6 months):
    • Restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge
    • Being easily fatigued
    • Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
    • Irritability
    • Muscle tension
    • Sleep disturbance (difficulty falling or staying asleep, or restless, unsatisfying sleep)
    • Note:  Only 1 symptom is required in children.
  • The anxiety, worry, or physical symptoms cause clinically significant distress, social or occupational impairment, or impairment in other important areas of functioning.
  • The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (eg, a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition (eg, hyperthyroidism).
  • The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder.

Differential diagnosis



  • Social anxiety disorder (SAD):  is also associated with anticipatory anxiety; however, the anxiety is limited to worries about being scrutinized in social situations.
  • Major depressive disorder (MDD):  can also involve anxiety, fatigue, insomnia, and concentration difficulties; however, a persistent low mood or anhedonia must be present MDD and GAD can be concurrent.
  • Illness anxiety disorder and somatic symptom disorder:  are also characterized by excessive anxiety about personal health and physical symptoms; however, additional worries about routine, everyday issues are not present.
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD):  can also involve recurrent negative thoughts and repetitive behaviors; however, obsessions usually follow a specific theme (eg, harm, contamination), and the resulting compulsions are not realistically associated (eg, counting to 3 upon entering a room to prevent sickness).

Diagnostic evaluation and work-up



Depending on clinical findings, diagnostic work-up may be indicated for other conditions that can present with anxiety symptoms (eg, hyperthyroidism, substance use).

Management



Management of GAD involves cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or pharmacotherapy depending on patient preference.  For severe symptoms, a combination of CBT and medications can be considered.

Cognitive behavioral therapy



  • Involves identifying and reframing automatic negative thoughts that contribute to anxiety and drive maladaptive behaviors
  • Exposes patient to anxiety-provoking situations in a guided and structured manner, resulting in improved tolerability and more accurate appraisals

Pharmacotherapy



  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) (eg, sertraline) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) (eg, venlafaxine) are first-line treatment due to their efficacy and tolerability.
  • Buspirone (serotonin [5-HT1A] receptor partial agonist) may be considered if the response to SSRI/SNRI is inadequate.  It is prescribed as monotherapy or as an augmenting agent.
  • Short-term hydroxyzine or benzodiazepine is adjunct treatment for severe symptoms and/or agitation/insomnia related to SSRI/SNRI titration.

Most patients have a concurrent psychiatric disorder:  MDD, other anxiety disorders, or substance use disorders.  Appropriate screening and treatment are recommended.

Prognosis



The majority of patients experience a chronic course with intermittent periods of remission.  Poor prognostic indicators include earlier age at onset and comorbid psychiatric conditions.
